content.description: Climb the dihedral using a variety of holds. The crux is the first sequence of moves to gain the low angle slab, the rest is V-easy. If only it were steeper…
content.protection: Pads and a spotter. Landing is ok, but a fall could shoot you right over them.
content.location: Southeast corner of the Butt Cheek Boulder. GPS is accurate.

content.description: Pick a line and go up. A few V0’s here.
content.location: North face of Butt Cheek Boulder.

content.description: Climb the leaning, overhung hand crack. The crux is getting past the bulge. It's possible to project on TR using a couple of large slings. Watch for nope ropes.
content.protection: Pads and spotters. Landing isn’t great.
content.location: East face of the Butt Cheek Boulder. GPS is accurate.

content.description: Sit start matched in the lower pocket, gain the slab, move left using the seam and top out left of the highest point on the boulder. Easier and more natural to follow the lip, though the feet are worse. Cover the hole or you might lose a leg. Contrived line.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter down low. Mind the hole.
content.location: 30 feet south of the Butt Cheek Boulder. GPS is accurate.

content.description: A small cluster of boulders near the bottom of the hill. The largest resembles butt cheeks.
